text: Yep. Unless statements, @ for instance variables, implicit function invocation (no parens), ? to indicate that a function returns a bool... that’s ruby. I forgot just how *big that language is.*

text: Me too! It used to be my favourite language to be honest. And even nowadays it ranks far higher than Python in my favourite list. I just never have a reason to use it...

text: I kind of like that we have function blocks with `function` in Julia, but at the same time it feels way too verbose.  I definitely don't like `def` because it sounds like it could be anything.  Maybe `func` as a comprompose would have been good, I don't know

text:
I like that `function` is a full word. I dislike abbreviations as keywords in a language. Probably the one I like least in a language is Python's `elif` :face_vomiting:.
I agree `function` can feel a little bit verbose, but Julia also has the `f(x) = ...` syntax for short functions so it balances out. If the function is large enough that it needs the full definition syntax, then `function` isn't that bad.

text: Couldn't agree more. `elif` is one of *many* things that at first I really missed when coming to julia from python, but have grown to loathe

text: Yeah, Ruby has `elsif`, like many other languages. It's marginally better, but at that point you might as well just have `elseif` like Julia. Maybe I'm a fast typer (I'm not!) But I don't think the extra letters are that much of a problem. Especially with autocompletion.

text: In any case, I'm so happy Julia syntax is more like Ruby's than Python's. That's one of the things that attracted me to the language first.
